For the national fast-day
Civil War Sermon
Civil War
PATRIOTISM etc ? Cot 4 Morais
Sermon/

Brethren! Were it my province to address an audience of non-Israelites,
I would, on the present occasion, select as my text a weighty sentence
which occurs in the 14th chapter of Exodus. It is the following דבר אל זני וכ"ו
מים על ים “The Eternal said to Moses, wherefore criest
thou unto me,? Bid the children of Israel go forward” When dearly bought
freedom is in jeopardy; when the angry billows of a political sea im=
=pede the march of civilization, and the adversaries of human brotherhood
are skillfully marshalled for the onslaught, deeds of self-denial more
than psalmody? will sanctify the life of man. The Lord of hosts will
be extolled by the efforts which tried to uphold truth, more than by
the fervent utterance of the lips. Let him therefore who values his
country's honor speed on, let him trustingly follow the path which
leads to national deliverance, and when the happy goal shall have
been attained, raise the anthem which will be reverberated ה' הושיעה המלך יעננו ביום וגו'
from sea to sea, even from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean.
Thus would I briefly speak this day, and dismiss a the greater assemblage.
But as my lot was cast among those who are singled out in their
belief and their worship, I deemed it expedient to adopt a different
course. A non-compliance of the Hebrew Community with the
counsel of the President of the United States, might at this jun=
=cture, have been open to animadversion. It therefore became

fit that we, who in our devotional outpourings at this solemn
season, ever tearfully remembered the sorrows of America, that we, who ceaselessly
pray for the welfare of the land of our adoption, and testified the love
we bear it, when at the first summons of the Executive we swelled the
ranks of her defenders, it became imperative, I say, that we should
nevertheless your own voices, this day also, to that of our fellow-citizens who
implore God for the restoration of peace. And verily, my friends!
Whatever opinion we may entertain touching the appositeness of the
request, our acquiescence therein will can be but the prompting of our
responsive sentiments feelings. This country, which many of you
claim at that of their birth, and some as that of them choice, has
not, like others that vaunt liberality, doled out her benefits to
you, O descendants of Jacob! but she has generously invited you
to participate in all the exuberance of her goods; hence, you as you did glory
in her happiness, and grieve over her distress. And when the custodian
of her liberties, descrying imminent danger, exhorts to prayer that it may be
averted, you who taught the world how to pray, will even at this hour
exclaim as you are wont אולי. “Save us O Lord, answer
us O King on this day that we call upon thy name”. But in
attuning our hearts to the national supplications, we receive an addition
=al incentive, in the present instance, by the remembrance that the
Chief Magistrate of our beloved Union, did not transcend the proper his limits, to

pander to the irregular wishes of a majority. His proclamation is
the exponent of that excellent provision in the American Constitution,
which forms its brightest ornament, but of which zealots are now
striving to divert it. Not they who tender divine adoration to the man
of Nazareth are exclusively recommended to beseech the living God for
the triumph of rightful authority over usurpation but the people at large, so that
the entreats of a whole nation ascending the throne of grace may bring
down plentiful blessings upon our afflicted country. Such, or the like,
are his words; very dissimilar my Brethren! from those of some high functionaries,
whose narrow views debar them from discerning beyond the pale
of their religion, an object worthy of any consideration. In confor
mity therefore with so discreet a summons, we will again pour
out our souls before the Omnipotent עושה במלאכה ואחת מחזקת השלחבאחת ידו
“Peradventure will He think on us, that we perish not” Yet But, the
prayer of freedom-loving Americans must be accompanied by deeds of
abnegation. I will repeat it: That Yonder sturdy man who in these
stirring times inactively contemplates the perilous state of the country Republic,
though he bow the head as a bulrush, mistakes the aim of his exist
=ence. When around the noblest monument of human wisdom,
fall destroyers have gathered, let the vigorous, like the ancient Hebrews
labour with one hand in the work of reconstruction, and wield in the
other a repelling sword. אין סומכין על הנס

the God of battles of will lead to victory. But if the patriotic ardour
that seemed to burn in every breast, when the national escutcheon was
first tarnished, has been quenched by the Liuthean? water of egotism;
if the memory of the past achievements and past glory contrasted with
the present humiliation does not arouse not in our midst the Leonidas, that
will struggle for the maintenance of this peerless Union; if the
taunts of the ungenerous foreigner, and the sardonic smile of despots,
are incapable of inspiriting all to energetic actions, the entreaties
offered this day will fail to propitrate the assistance of the Most High.
בעון בצעו קצפתי ואכהו הסתר ואקצף וילך שובב בדרך לבו, is a wise aphorism of Israel's ancient Teachers.
“We must not rely on miracles” Nothing is impossible to Him
who inspired a Gideon, and by three hundred of the faithful, put to flight
the redoubtable best army of Midian, but while we it behooves us to beseech
Him and confide in his support for the ultimate success of a
righteous cause we must labour for our salvation. we must render ourselves deserving of it by prefer=
=ring to individual promotion, national honor, national greatness Unity,
national peace. Shall I now point out, how the pursuing of
the opposite course, became the bane of America,? how personal
ambition becomes the vampire that fed on her life's blood? How self-
interest gave birth to parasites who scampered with the rich spoil of
their unsuspecting host? Shall I say, that even at this hour, when

the tocsin resounds which tells the world that the pioneer of civil
and religious liberty is verging on a precipice, men—shall I call them
men, no, heartless and soulless beings—are found, who will turn
to profit the mighty struggles of the brave to escape the yawning gulf? Noy,
let others enumerate the sins which have exposed the country of
Washington to the contumely of the stranger and the horrors of war.
I will rather deplore them and acknowledge the justice of the Divine
? verdict דרכיו ראיתי וארפאהו ואנחהו ואשלם נחמים לו ולאבליו
“For the inequity of his covetousness was I wrath, and smote him, I hid
myself and was indignant, for he went on forwardly in the way of
his heart”. This sentence of Isaiah so applicable to your unhappy
condition, O my hearers, reveals the plague which has putrified the
channels whence have sprung these waters of Meribah (contention). Yet, it lies
in your power to convert them again into refreshing streams of Hebrew
brotherhood. God showed you the tree that will sweeten those
bitter waters, in the example of your immortal predecessors.
Let the memory of their sterling virtues cluster around your minds, and
awaken them to deeds of magnanimous valour, let them counsel
the renunciation of all preconceived thoughts notions for the preservation of
this palladium of human rights, the total subjugation of selfishness
for the benefit prosperity of the common country, the repudiation of all

doctrines subversive of the principles which they who framed the
Declaration of your independence unequivocally for the spread of civilization enunciated; then will
you regain the attitude from whence you were ruthlessly & unnaturally cast forced down,
or, to continue in the language of the prophet “God will see your ways and
heal you, He will guide you securely, and restore comforts to you and those
who mourn for your sorrows Hebrew
And this day which a spirit of meekness has devoted to sacred communion,
will be the opening of a new era, glorious to America, and fruitful
of joy to the whole human race.

Lord God! who didst bless this land with Thy favour, restore her, we
beseech Thee, to Unity. Cancel her inequities, and let her be distinguished
anew for the virginal purity of her pristine years. Grant that
charity and truth may weave the garland that shall adorn her children,
for then will righteousness and peace be met in her midst clasped in each
mutual, others others' embrace. Guide Thou the steps which are now wending toward
the conquest of national supremacy over faction, that they may not
overreach the bounds justly prefixed. Oh! Eternal Being who didst
rekindle the long suppressed feelings of love in the bosom of the fierce
son of Isaac, breathe into us words of brotherly reconciliation, and let the hand
that wields the sword be mutually, grasped fraternally seized with a mutual grasp fraternal pressure. At this
hour, when the heart of a whole nation is upheaved to Thee, calm
O Omnipotent! its inward perturbation. Regard the prayer which

in various strains but in consonance of thoughts is addressed to Thee;
let the angels of mercy present it to the throne of grace, and bring
down thy fatherly blessing upon thy suppliants, even, honor, Union
and peace for evermore. Amen.

body.p:
at a special meeting of the Faculty of Maimonides College held
in consequence of the sad? bereavement recently sustained by
the house of Israel, the following preamble and resolutions were
unanimously adopted

Whereas the demise of the Revd Isaac Leeser is deemed by
each of us a national loss, and whereas it is our conviction
that the establishing of this institution was principally due
to the unremitting exertions of our late colaborer, and to his
constant advocacy of religious education, therefore

Resolved that we express our feelings of deep sorrow at the
loss of a man so zealous for the moral welfare of his people,
so energetic in promoting the culture of human knowledge, so
efficient as a professor, so exemplary assiduous in the discharge
of all his duties.

Resolved that we gladly descry bearing our testimony to the uniform kindness and
courtesy that marked his official relations with us, and to
his timely and useful suggestions as the Provost of this College

Resolved that we will ever cherish his memory as that of a friend,
and teach our the students of this Institution to revere his memory name

Resolved that these resolutions be published in one of our dailies & in all Jewish
periodicals; and
